content.text: Endophthalmitis is a rare but devastating complication of glaucoma filtering surgery (e.g., trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation). The presence of a filtering bleb or an implanted device creates a potential pathway for microorganisms to enter the eye. Infections can be acute (occurring within 6 weeks of surgery) or delayed/chronic (occurring months to years later). Bleb-related endophthalmitis is particularly challenging.

pairs.value: Thin, avascular, or leaking blebs; use of antifibrotic agents (mitomycin C, 5-fluorouracil); blepharitis; conjunctivitis; and inferiorly located blebs.
Coagulase-negative staphylococci (e.g., S. epidermidis), Staphylococcus aureus. Similar to post-cataract surgery endophthalmitis.
Streptococcus species, Haemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis are more common in bleb-related infections and are often more virulent.

content.text: This is an infection confined to the filtering bleb itself. The bleb appears opacified or milky (a "white-on-red" appearance), with surrounding conjunctival injection. There is no or minimal anterior chamber inflammation, and vision is usually good. It is considered a precursor to endophthalmitis.

The infection has spread from the bleb into the eye. This presents with all the signs of blebitis plus significant intraocular inflammation, including anterior chamber cells and flare, hypopyon, vitritis, decreased vision, and pain. This is an ophthalmic emergency.
Immediate referral to an ophthalmologist is critical.

appliesTo.description: Patients with infection limited to the bleb

components.dose: e.g., fortified vancomycin and tobramycin, or a fluoroquinolone

regimenData.notes: Close monitoring is essential to ensure it does not progress to endophthalmitis. Some clinicians may also use oral antibiotics.

This follows the same principles as post-surgical endophthalmitis. An aqueous/vitreous tap for culture is performed, followed by immediate injection of broad-spectrum intravitreal antibiotics. Pars plana vitrectomy may be indicated, especially given the high virulence of common pathogens like Streptococcus.

content.text: The visual prognosis for bleb-related endophthalmitis is generally poor, often worse than for post-cataract surgery endophthalmitis, due to the more virulent organisms typically involved. Prompt recognition and treatment are key to salvaging vision.
